Mike, so refreshing to read your words.  I agree with your description of the Mexican people, understanding this is a generalization, but truly speaks to their nature.  Could go on and on about this,  as it is something I feel strongly about.  But I won't.  I will continue to look forward to any interactions I have with the Hispanics in my area.  I feel welcomed at their smallish groceries where I shop frequently.  ALWAYS receive smiles.  That is important to me.  I hope the smiles I return somehow offer reassurance and kindness.  Enough said.

I've lived in southern Mexico for six months and met only two Mexicans with a desire to go to the US. One was a felon who was deported from Atlanta, who wanted to return illegally (I talked him out of it), and the other was a guy who had connections in Las Vegas, who wanted to hire him to trim marijuana buds. He is still here. North Americans have distorted ideas about the Mexican people; they are strong, generous, family-oriented, calm, self-controlled, and hard-working people. Dignity means a lot to even the poorest of them, and self-respect is a mark of their character. Many know that to work in the US means to confront daily the racist remarks and discrimination by whites and blacks alike. I have never heard a Mexican shout at an English-speaking North American, "Speak English!", as I heard a southern white storekeeper shout at a poor Mexican worker who spoke little of it. Most Americans don't know that it was through the hard and underpaid work of about 30,000 Mexican laborers, carpenters, and others, who rebuilt most of New Orleans after the devastation of Hurricane Katrina.
Money talks.

While on vacation in Mexico with a large group, I was speaking in Spanish to a waiter and was corrected for doing so by a member of our group, a friend of a friend. "Speak English!", she demanded. I reminded her where we were and told her that you are supposed to speak Mexican while in Mexico. (Sometimes you have to break it down for people.) It was pretty shocking to me.

Another well reported but surprisingly obscure fact is that Hispanics in the US are learning English at a faster rate than any previous group of immigrants. German, Italian, Chinese and Japanese immigrants didn't take advantage of language learning audio and video programs and didn't watch television to learn English. I'd pop a cassette in while driving to work to study Spanish. One can make a lot of progress that way.

Unfortunately, English is a mashup of Romance and Germanic languages which makes it hard to master. Our spelling is beyond idiotic. Poor Predident Theodore Roosevelt was derided savagely for attempting to make it more reasonable, like the Spanish and Germans do. Instead we went the French way and enshrined spelling that has been archaic for centuries.

Re Daniel and English.

Indeed, our spelling is beyond idiotic, but our grammar is child's play. In English, you memorize three or four conjugations for almost every verb; in Spanish it can run to 10 times that many.
I meant to say that I never heard a Mexican shout, "Speak Spanish!" to a language-deficient North American, as I heard a white southern storekeeper shout, "Speak English!" at a poor Mexican worker.

Please understand that the ages of the children in a class do not drive curriculum. Public schools across the country adopt similar standards and use similar materials to teach similar skills.

And your children are not competing in kindergarten. Instead, they are being evaluated by a set of criteria that has been determined in advance. (The regular standards for most, an IEP for exceptional students.) Having older or bigger or smarter kids in class will not change the expectations for yours.

And as a kindergarten teacher for 35 years, I do not agree with the aggressive standards that have been developed for 5-year-olds. Many kids still come to school unprepared for its rigor and without readiness skills. And I think kindergartners should be 5 when they start. I wonder why NYC (or is it the state?) still has such a late cutoff date.

But I wonder about a lot of things in other places. Like why in so many states some districts have so much more to spend on schools than others. And why mayors are in charge of city schools at all.

What is probably a major obstacle on the way of some simulative moves is staggering numbers of debt on the country like Greece or Cyprus. The populations of those countries are very small. The underlying, native economy is very modest. Major economic drivers are shipping, tourism, and banking. They are operated for the benefits of foreigners, not for the benefit of locals. The only decent way of life in those countries was government or quasi-government employment. The governments there were forced to under tax the entities that were all the time on the verge of leaving the country. You can run shipping from Liberia, set up resorts in Turkey and Egypt, and bank just about anywhere, like the Isle of Man. In the same time nice looking countries in close proximity to the core inspired unabated trust in lenders that now come to be regretful for giving in to deceptive looks. The lending to the countries on the south of Europe has old roots stretching to the cold war. All those countries are relatively poor and used to be very left leaning. To prop up centrist social democratic governments friendly to the West the system of lending was set up. That created two different ways of life – one modest and based on real economic conditions on the ground and another based on money borrowed from abroad, and often gov. centered. Now it is a time of reckoning. The funniest thing, it is not even clear if those countries can go into repayment mode. In all those years post WWII they never tried.

More excerpts on civility from Didi Kirsten Tatlow’s replies:

-----

Remember: with freedom comes responsibility. Please exercise it and remain courteous.

A moderator needs to promote discourse. We care about debate here, about dialogue, and for that reason work to protect it from the incivility that destroys true debate.

For everyone debating this issue, can I recommend you read this very interesting story about a study on the impact of anger/negativity in online debate which I just saw on the NYT. The conclusion, basically, is that tone really matters, and that negativity and anger can actually distort the issue in a substantive way. This is why I've been asking for calm and respectful debate all along.

Some individual facts can be established…..this can be done with a spirit of shared truth-seeking and it can be done civily. There has been little civility in this debate and I think the anger we've seen from some quarters gives something away. To focus on details while ignoring the 800 pound elephant in the room is hard to justify on intellectual, moral, psychological and logical grounds.

I believe the debate on this site became markedly more civil after I called for greater respect and I'm very glad about that. I hope it means that this is a good place to talk and also that when we interact, the good stuff comes out.

We would like [to] maintain a respectful and calm debate here.

Have a nice day everyone. Thanks for your participation.

The arguments that support a free market "uber alles" does not square with reality or human nature. Just a little thinking about health insurance & healthcare will lead one to conclude that the consumer of health treatments & services does not really have a choice. It is impossible for an ill person to choose his healthcare provider by price & quality of service. One simply does not have any choice so competition does not work. I am aware of the propaganda that your health should be between you & your doctor & how we make a competitive healthcare system seem warm, fuzzy and personal, but it is not.

I listen to the call-ins to C-Span and hear the stories of the horrors of free healthcare clinics in the UK but I believe we should move as quickly as possible to Medicare for all & then health clinics & hospitals with salaried staffs paid by rank in a national health care system. Medical schools should accept the best and the brightest as if they were midshipmen who were preparing for a medical career.

Our system is seriously flawed & Obamacare is the first step to achieving a higher level of care & health outcomes. Results not money should be driving this system, anyhow.

For the super rich who don't want to mingle with the masses, I am almost certain that there will be some off-shore healthcare establishments where they can pay for the very best. I remember when Onassis was taking injections of stuff made of lamb fetuses to stimulate his performance.

I'm not an expert, but I believe that the special concern about GMOs comes from the fact that genes from widely disparate organisms can be (and are) inserted into food crops. Traditional breeding involves closely related plant species with a more limited range of potential outcomes.

I do not believe I am alone in thinking it unlikely that a fish and a plant could be interbred by any conventional means. The results of such a combination should be carefully considered as there would appear to be a larger range of potential unintended consequences.

Genetically modified food crops are being used as a means to produce human prescription medicines at low cost. If these drug-producing genes find their way into regular crops (as has already happened with other GMOs) we will find prescription drugs in our breakfast cereal. Even ten years ago drug crop contamination was a problem: http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v21/n1/full/nbt0103-3b.html.

Starlink GMO corn was intended only for animal feed as it was thought to be a potential human allergen. Then it showed up in Taco Bell and myriad other foods: http://www.fas.org/biosecurity/education/dualuse-agriculture/2.-agricult...

If GMOs can do amazingly beneficial things then it stands to reason that mistakes could be equally amazing. It seems wise to carefully weigh the potential benefits against the potential costs, especially since any damage is likely to be difficult to predict and irreversible.

Wow! What a screed from someone so open-minded!

I understand that you're not a scientist but you're not much of an economist either. You assume that this is a fair market. When, if you were truly open-minded, you'd recognize that, in fact, it simply is not. This is a market that is simply being bought by a few very powerful lobbyists.

Markets are skewed all the time: We use the QWERTY keyboard not because it was the best but because it was the best marketed. Nestle's turned the developing world on to SIMILAC not because it was best for women's and children's health - it was, in fact, worse - but because they could afford to sell their message better than public health advocates.

Open-minded, no. What you are is a remarkably biased reader of facts - both scientific and otherwise. There is absolutely no reference to "the government" telling us which methods of production are more economical but that's what you read into it. You question why independent testing should be the norm for a newly introduced technology as if you learned nothing from the introduction of thalidomide or silicone breast implants.

The fact is that you haven't "heard" any evidence that this new technology has shown poor results, is bringing with it the rise of new resistant strains of pests, is limiting the source of seeds in some of our most important grain products, is behind the ten-fold use in the amount of toxic pesticides used in farming...simply because you're not listening.

@David Westerfeld

Good points, thank you.

@ Bill

Setting aside the personal insults, I disagree with the substance of your reply.

1) Bittman claims GMO's aren't cost effective. I start from the premise that market forces are *usually* the best way to determine the value of goods and services (do you disagree?). Neither Bittman or you has presented any evidence that there is some market failure that has caused a systematic overinvestment in GMOs. The normal market failure (asymmetric information, for example), would cause underinvestment in GMO's, not overinvestment.

2) Bittman (and you) are skeptical of the value of market forces determining the value of GMO's. What is the solution to the "problem" of overly-costly GMO technology, if not non-market (i.e. governmet) evaluation of cost effectiveness?

The fact is that modern non-GMO crops are radically different from their "natural" ancestors. The anti-GMO lobby generally ignores that reality.

Mr. Bittman,

You claim that GMO's are both disappointing, except where companies like Monsanto have made big profits. What? Monsanto doesn't make money without farmers buying their products, and if their products are popular, doesn't that suggest they aren't so "disappointing"?

You criticize GMO's for being more expensive than comparable technologies. Since when are Government bureaucrats are the best arbiters of whether a product produces societal benefits? To the extent GMO crops are not cost-effective, the market will surely take care of that problem.

Of course, you also speculate that GMO's create externalities that warrant government regulation. To that point, you support testing for harm from GMOs. Can you explain why GMO's merit a different testing regime than crops developed with any other breeding method? All agricultural innovation uses "genetics," by virtue of the fact that conventional breeders select for desireable traits. Do you deny that that process has unintended consequences?

Please trust me when I say I have an open mind on GMO's (i'm not a scientist by any means). But I'm skeptical about your position because I haven't heard one shred of proof (or even a plausible hypothesis) explaining why GMO's pose a unique risk to health and safety beyond normal breeding methods. To my mind, GMO crusaders on the left seem just as ideological and anti-science as global warming deniers on the right.
